messages.message: Is gdrive not supported anymore? I cannot figure out how to add it in again
if you go to “My Hub”, you should see “Drives” on the right, and you click the plus icon to add a drive
ah i was under org settings
we do not support gdrive for orgs? correct
hmm we should support gdrive for orgs, are you not able to add a gdrive?
what environment are you using?
prod
oh i see, i misunderstood your question
correct, google drives can only be added as workspace drives

this is mentioned in our docs, but our docs are currently inaccessible (https://instabase.slack.com/archives/C06FA6A23/p1715098659800219) :upside_down_face:

so here’s a link to the docs in our github repo https://github.com/instabase/aihub-docs/blob/preview/content/admin/connect-drives.md
how can i run an app into a gdrive?
since you cannot make a gdrive a default drive

hmm good question, i agree that it seems impossible - we only allow the selection of a workspace when running an app, so app runs will always go into that workspace’s default drive

however, it seems that google drives can never be the default drive for a workspace - is that correct? @Xindi Xu
Yes. Google drives can't be a default drive
why?
This is a technical limitation. @Cheryl Zhou would you explain further? ty!

To be a default drive, the file client has to support a set of write related functionalities. The API provided by GDrive is a very basic one that doesn't have all these functionalities (cc @Yash Botadra to elaborate), so we cannot implement a file client on top of it that will be able to do these required functionalities. The GDrive client we have now is mostly read-only, and it's not fully capable of becoming the default drive, where projects/conversations will be stored on
Why do we ask for write and delete access ?

making a drive default means that we'll write intermediary files from Build/Converse to the drive, so we need write access. We also need to clean up these files when deleting projects, so we need delete access.
But if you cannot make it a default how does it write to it
Right. Because we can't get write and delete access from Google Drives, we can't allow users to set Google drives as default drives.
I guess my question is why do we ask for write and delete access in the google permissions then

> The API provided by GDrive is a very basic one that doesn't have all these functionalities, so we cannot implement a file client on top of it that will be able to do these required functionalities.
Unlike S3, when connecting Google Drives, the users don't have the option to grant us permissions

We support exporting the results of an app run to Google Drive. So we need write access. We don’t need delete though.
There is an item in the backlog to ask for fine-grained permissions (start off with read-only and then ask for write if needed) but there doesn’t seem to be a huge ask for it so it hasn’t been prioritized.
